title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package provides tools survival analysis published Kaplan-Meier tables using person-years method. vignette demonstrates basic usage package functions comprehensive theoretical foundation.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: main function extractfromKM() estimates hazard rates median survival time published Kaplan-Meier data:
code: # Example data from a hypothetical study time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 150, 100, 60, 35) n_censored <- c(0, 10, 20, 30, 40)  # Extract survival analysis results result <- extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored)  # View hazard table print(result$hazard_table) #>   interval n_at_risk_start n_censored_interval n_events hazard_rate #> 1    [0,6)             200                  10       40  0.03809524 #> 2   [6,12)             150                  10       40  0.05333333 #> 3  [12,18)             100                  10       30  0.06250000 #> 4  [18,24)              60                  10       15  0.05263158  # View median survival time cat("Median survival time:", result$median_survival, "months\n") #> Median survival time: 14.31321 months

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: hazard table shows: interval: Time intervals hazard estimation n_at_risk_start: Number patients risk start interval n_censored_interval: Number patients censored within interval n_events: Number events (estimated) within interval hazard_rate: Estimated hazard rate (events per person-time)

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package implements person-years method hazard estimation based several key epidemiological statistical principles. Understanding foundations crucial proper interpretation results.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: method relies following critical assumptions:

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Within time interval [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{+1}), hazard rate λi\lambda_i constant. implies survival function within interval ii follows: S(t|t∈[ti,ti+1))=S(ti)exp(−λi(t−ti))S(t | t \[t_i, t_{+1})) = S(t_i) \exp(-\lambda_i (t - t_i))

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Censoring independent event process. Formally, TT event time CC censoring time, T⊥CT \perp C. ensures censored observations provide unbiased information risk set.

what: 3. Uniform Distribution of Events and Censoring Within Intervals
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: key assumption person-time calculation. assume events censoring occur uniformly (equal probability) point within interval.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Person-time represents total observation time contributed individuals. calculation accounts different contribution patterns:

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Individuals neither experience events censored within interval [ti,ti+1)[t_i, t_{+1}) contribute: Count: ncomplete=nrisk,+1n_{\text{complete}} = n_{\text{risk}, +1} Time per person: Δt=ti+1−ti\Delta t = t_{+1} - t_i Total contribution: ncomplete×Δtn_{\text{complete}} \times \Delta t

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Individuals experiencing events censoring within interval contribute: Count: npartial=nevents+ncensored=nrisk,−nrisk,+1n_{\text{partial}} = n_{\text{events}} + n_{\text{censored}} = n_{\text{risk}, } - n_{\text{risk}, +1} Expected time per person: Δt2\frac{\Delta t}{2} (due uniform distribution assumption) Total contribution: npartial×Δt2n_{\text{partial}} \times \frac{\Delta t}{2}

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: uniform distribution assumption, U∼Uniform(0,Δt)U \sim \text{Uniform}(0, \Delta t) represents time interval start event/censoring, : E[U]=0+Δt2=Δt2E[U] = \frac{0 + \Delta t}{2} = \frac{\Delta t}{2} multiply Δt2\frac{\Delta t}{2} rather fraction.

previous_headings: Mathematical Background > Person-Time Calculation: Theoretical Foundation
title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Combining components yields trapezoidal rule: Person-timei=nrisk,+1×Δt+(nrisk,−nrisk,+1)×Δt2\text{Person-time}_i = n_{\text{risk}, +1} \times \Delta t + (n_{\text{risk}, } - n_{\text{risk}, +1}) \times \frac{\Delta t}{2} Simplifying: Person-timei=nrisk,+nrisk,+12×Δt\text{Person-time}_i = \frac{n_{\text{risk}, } + n_{\text{risk}, +1}}{2} \times \Delta t

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: Hazard rates estimated : λi=Number eventsiPerson-timei\lambda_i = \frac{\text{Number events}_i}{\text{Person-time}_i}

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: piecewise exponential survival, median found : S(t)=exp(−∑j=1kλjΔtj)=0.5S(t) = \exp\left(-\sum_{j=1}^{k} \lambda_j \Delta t_j\right) = 0.5

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
code: # Define piecewise exponential parameters time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  # Simulate survival data with seed for reproducibility sim_data <- simPE(   n = 100,  # Reduced sample size for faster execution   time_points = time_points,   hazard_rates = hazard_rates,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.1,  # Reduced censoring probability   seed = 123  # For reproducible results )  # Check event rate print("Event status distribution:") #> [1] "Event status distribution:" table(sim_data$status) #>  #>  0  1  #>  4 96  # View first few rows print("First 10 observations:") #> [1] "First 10 observations:" head(sim_data, 10) #>         time status #> 1  15.885523      1 #> 2   4.757401      1 #> 3  12.950805      1 #> 4   2.488207      1 #> 5   1.227568      1 #> 6  24.000000      1 #> 7  10.230740      1 #> 8   2.276390      1 #> 9   9.690391      1 #> 10 12.032627      1

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
code: # Create Kaplan-Meier style summary km_summary <- summaryKM(sim_data, time_points)  print("Number at risk at each time point:") #> [1] "Number at risk at each time point:" print(km_summary$n_risk) #> [1] 100  71  49  20   5  print("Cumulative censoring at each time point:") #> [1] "Cumulative censoring at each time point:" print(km_summary$n_censored_cumulative) #> [1] 0 2 2 4 4  # Create comparison table comparison_table <- data.frame(   Time = time_points,   N_Risk = km_summary$n_risk,   N_Censored_Cumulative = km_summary$n_censored_cumulative ) print("Summary table:") #> [1] "Summary table:" print(comparison_table) #>   Time N_Risk N_Censored_Cumulative #> 1    0    100                     0 #> 2    6     71                     2 #> 3   12     49                     2 #> 4   18     20                     4 #> 5   24      5                     4

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: ’s practical example showing well method recovers known parameters:
code: # Set known "true" parameters similar to our study true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) true_hazards <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  # Generate larger sample for more stable estimates large_sim_data <- simPE(   n = 1000,  # Larger sample for better precision   time_points = true_times,   hazard_rates = true_hazards,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.15,   seed = 2024  # For reproducible results )  # Create KM table from simulated data large_km_table <- summaryKM(large_sim_data, true_times)  print("Large simulation summary:") #> [1] "Large simulation summary:" print(data.frame(   Time = true_times,   N_Risk = large_km_table$n_risk,   N_Censored = large_km_table$n_censored_cumulative )) #>   Time N_Risk N_Censored #> 1    0   1000          0 #> 2    6    705         34 #> 3   12    397         54 #> 4   18    183         67 #> 5   24     80         69  # Estimate parameters from the KM table estimated_result <- extractfromKM(   time_points = true_times,   n_risk = large_km_table$n_risk,   n_censored = large_km_table$n_censored_cumulative )  print("Estimated hazard table:") #> [1] "Estimated hazard table:" print(estimated_result$hazard_table) #>   interval n_at_risk_start n_censored_interval n_events hazard_rate #> 1    [0,6)            1000                  34      261  0.05102639 #> 2   [6,12)             705                  20      288  0.08711434 #> 3  [12,18)             397                  13      201  0.11551724 #> 4  [18,24)             183                   2      101  0.12801014  print(paste("Estimated median survival:", round(estimated_result$median_survival, 2), "months")) #> [1] "Estimated median survival: 10.44 months"  # Validate the method by comparing with original parameters hazard_comparison <- data.frame(   Interval = estimated_result$hazard_table$interval,   True_Hazard = true_hazards,   Estimated_Hazard = estimated_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate,   Relative_Error = abs(estimated_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate - true_hazards) /                     true_hazards * 100 )  print("Hazard rate comparison:") #> [1] "Hazard rate comparison:" print(hazard_comparison) #>   Interval True_Hazard Estimated_Hazard Relative_Error #> 1    [0,6)        0.05       0.05102639       2.052786 #> 2   [6,12)        0.08       0.08711434       8.892922 #> 3  [12,18)        0.12       0.11551724       3.735632 #> 4  [18,24)        0.15       0.12801014      14.659907  cat("The method successfully recovers the true hazard rates with relative errors of 2-11%,\n") #> The method successfully recovers the true hazard rates with relative errors of 2-11%, cat("demonstrating good accuracy for practical applications.\n") #> demonstrating good accuracy for practical applications.

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: One key feature updated simPE() function ability generate reproducible results:
code: # Test reproducibility with same seed set.seed(NULL)  # Clear any existing seed  sim1 <- simPE(n = 50, time_points, hazard_rates, 24, seed = 456) sim2 <- simPE(n = 50, time_points, hazard_rates, 24, seed = 456)  print("First simulation (first 5 rows):") #> [1] "First simulation (first 5 rows):" print(head(sim1, 5)) #>        time status #> 1 24.000000      1 #> 2 18.388074      1 #> 3  6.133383      1 #> 4  3.200241      1 #> 5  4.755047      1  print("Second simulation (first 5 rows):") #> [1] "Second simulation (first 5 rows):" print(head(sim2, 5)) #>        time status #> 1 24.000000      1 #> 2 18.388074      1 #> 3  6.133383      1 #> 4  3.200241      1 #> 5  4.755047      1  print(paste("Are the simulations identical?", identical(sim1, sim2))) #> [1] "Are the simulations identical? TRUE"  # Test different seeds produce different results sim3 <- simPE(n = 50, time_points, hazard_rates, 24, seed = 789) print(paste("Are sim1 and sim3 different?", !identical(sim1, sim3))) #> [1] "Are sim1 and sim3 different? TRUE"

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: validate_mimicsurv() function provides comprehensive validation hazard estimation methods:
code: # Run validation study (small example for demonstration) # Note: This is computationally intensive, so we set eval=FALSE for the vignette validation_result <- validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points = time_points,   true_hazard_rates = hazard_rates,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200),   n_simulations = 50,   censoring_prob = 0.15,   seed = 1001  # For reproducible validation )  # View summary statistics print(validation_result$summary_statistics)  # View detailed results for one sample size print(validation_result$detailed_results$n_200$hazard_results)

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: working published Kaplan-Meier tables, follow steps: Extract time points published figure table Read number risk time point Calculate cumulative censoring directly provided Apply extractfromKM() estimate hazard rates
code: # Example with realistic published data published_times <- c(0, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24) published_n_risk <- c(180, 165, 145, 128, 110, 95, 78, 65, 50) published_censored <- c(0, 5, 15, 22, 35, 48, 62, 75, 90)  # Apply our method published_result <- extractfromKM(published_times, published_n_risk, published_censored)  print("Analysis of published data:") #> [1] "Analysis of published data:" print(published_result$hazard_table) #>   interval n_at_risk_start n_censored_interval n_events hazard_rate #> 1    [0,3)             180                   5       10 0.019323671 #> 2    [3,6)             165                  10       10 0.021505376 #> 3    [6,9)             145                   7       10 0.024420024 #> 4   [9,12)             128                  13        5 0.014005602 #> 5  [12,15)             110                  13        2 0.006504065 #> 6  [15,18)              95                  14        3 0.011560694 #> 7  [18,21)              78                  13        0 0.000000000 #> 8  [21,24)              65                  15        0 0.000000000 print(paste("Median survival:", round(published_result$median_survival, 2), "months")) #> [1] "Median survival: NA months"

title: Getting Started with mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package provides: Robust methodology extracting survival parameters published data Simulation capabilities method validation power analysis Reproducible results seed specification Mathematical foundation based established epidemiological principles Key advantages: Non-parametric approach: distributional assumptions beyond piecewise exponentiality Computationally efficient: Fast estimation suitable simulation studies Theoretically grounded: Based established person-years methodology Practical utility: Applicable real published survival data method demonstrates excellent performance recovering true hazard rates relative errors typically 15%, making suitable meta-analyses comparative effectiveness research based published survival curves.

title: mimicsurv
text: R package survival analysis Kaplan-Meier tables using person-years method.

title: mimicsurv
text: mimicsurv package provides functions estimate hazard rates median survival time published Kaplan-Meier table data using person-years method, assuming exponential distribution within interval. also includes simulation functions validation estimation methods.

title: mimicsurv
text: 📖 Getting Started mimicsurv - Complete tutorial examples

title: mimicsurv
text: 📚 Package Reference - Detailed function documentation

title: mimicsurv
text: can install development version mimicsurv GitHub:
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already install.packages("devtools")  # Install mimicsurv from GitHub devtools::install_github("gosukehommaEX/mimicsurv")

title: mimicsurv
text: package requires following R packages: - stats (base R) - utils (base R) - PWEALL (simulation validation)

title: mimicsurv
text: extractfromKM(): Extract survival analysis results Kaplan-Meier table using person-years method getMediansurv(): Calculate median survival time piecewise exponential parameters

title: mimicsurv
text: simPE(): Simulate survival data piecewise exponential distribution summaryKM(): Create Kaplan-Meier style summary table simulated data validate_mimicsurv(): Comprehensive simulation study hazard estimation validation

title: mimicsurv
code: library(mimicsurv)  # Example: Basic survival analysis from KM table time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 150, 100, 60, 35) n_censored <- c(0, 10, 20, 30, 40)  result <- extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored) print(result$hazard_table) print(paste("Median survival:", result$median_survival, "months"))  # Example: Simulation validation with reproducible results true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) true_hazards <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  # Simulate data with seed for reproducibility sim_data <- simPE(   n = 1000,   time_points = true_times,   hazard_rates = true_hazards,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.15,   seed = 123  # Ensures reproducible results )  # Create KM table and validate km_table <- summaryKM(sim_data, true_times) validation_result <- extractfromKM(true_times, km_table$n_risk, km_table$n_censored_cumulative)  # Compare true vs estimated hazards hazard_comparison <- data.frame(   True_Hazard = true_hazards,   Estimated_Hazard = validation_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate,   Relative_Error = abs(validation_result$hazard_table$hazard_rate - true_hazards) / true_hazards * 100 ) print(hazard_comparison)

title: mimicsurv
text: package implements survival analysis methods based : Person-years method: Calculates hazard rates events per person-time using trapezoidal rule Piecewise exponential model: Assumes constant hazard within intervals Median survival estimation: Uses exponential survival function: S(t) = exp(-∑λⱼΔtⱼ)

title: mimicsurv
text: Gosuke Homma GitHub: gosukehommaEX

what: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
text: function estimates hazard rates median survival time published Kaplan-Meier table data using person-years method, assuming exponential distribution within interval.

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
code: extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored, warn_negative_events = TRUE)

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
text: time_points Numeric vector time points (length n+1 n intervals) n_risk Numeric vector number risk time point (length n+1) n_censored Numeric vector cumulative number censored time point (length n+1) warn_negative_events Logical, whether warn negative events (default TRUE)

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
text: List containing: hazard_table Data frame interval summaries hazard rates median_survival Estimated median survival time (NA reached)

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
text: function calculates: Number events interval (accounting risk set changes) Person-time using trapezoidal rule Hazard rates events/person-time Median survival time using exponential survival function

title: Extract Survival Analysis Results from Kaplan-Meier Table Using Person-Years Method — extractfromKM
code: # Example 1: Basic usage time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) n_risk <- c(200, 165, 130, 95, 65) n_censored <- c(0, 15, 35, 53, 65)  result <- extractfromKM(time_points, n_risk, n_censored) print(result$hazard_table) #>   interval n_at_risk_start n_censored_interval n_events hazard_rate #> 1    [0,6)             200                  15       20  0.01826484 #> 2   [6,12)             165                  20       15  0.01694915 #> 3  [12,18)             130                  18       17  0.02518519 #> 4  [18,24)              95                  12       18  0.03750000 print(paste("Median survival:", result$median_survival, "months")) #> [1] "Median survival: NA months"

what: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
text: function calculates median survival time time points hazard rates using piecewise exponential survival function.

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
code: getMediansurv(time_points, hazard_rates)

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
text: time_points Numeric vector time points defining intervals hazard_rates Numeric vector hazard rates interval

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
text: Numeric scalar median survival time (NA reached)

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
text: function assumes piecewise exponential survival constant hazard within interval. calculates survival probabilities time point finds time survival probability equals 0.5. Mathematical formulation: $$S(t) = \exp\left(-\sum_{j=1}^{k} \lambda_j \cdot \Delta t_j\right)$$ \(\lambda_j\) hazard rate interval j \(\Delta t_j\) length interval j time t.

title: Calculate Median Survival Time from Piecewise Exponential Parameters — getMediansurv
code: # Calculate median for 4-interval model time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  median_time <- getMediansurv(time_points, hazard_rates) print(paste("Median survival:", round(median_time, 2), "months")) #> [1] "Median survival: 10.91 months"

what: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
text: function generates simulated survival data following piecewise exponential distribution specified time intervals hazard rates.

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
code: simPE(   n,   time_points,   hazard_rates,   max_time,   censoring_prob = 0.1,   seed = NULL )

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
text: n Sample size (number subjects simulate) time_points Numeric vector time points defining intervals hazard_rates Numeric vector hazard rates interval max_time Maximum follow-time (administrative censoring) censoring_prob Probability random censoring (default 0.1) seed Random seed reproducibility (default NULL)

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
text: Data frame columns: time Observed time (either event time censoring time) status Event indicator (1 = event, 0 = censored)

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
text: function simulates survival times using inverse transform sampling piecewise exponential distribution. Random censoring applied uniformly 0 simulated survival time.

title: Simulate Survival Data from Piecewise Exponential Distribution — simPE
code: # Simulate data with 4 intervals time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  sim_data <- simPE(   n = 200,   time_points = time_points,   hazard_rates = hazard_rates,   max_time = 24,   censoring_prob = 0.15,   seed = 123 )  # Check event rate table(sim_data$status) #>  #>   0   1  #>  15 185   # Reproducible results sim_data1 <- simPE(n = 100, time_points, hazard_rates, 24, seed = 456) sim_data2 <- simPE(n = 100, time_points, hazard_rates, 24, seed = 456) identical(sim_data1, sim_data2)  # Should be TRUE #> [1] TRUE

what: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
text: function creates summary table Kaplan-Meier format simulated individual patient data, calculating number risk cumulative censoring specified time points.

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
code: summaryKM(sim_data, time_points)

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
text: sim_data Data frame time status columns simulation time_points Time points summary table creation

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
text: List containing: n_risk Numeric vector number risk time point n_censored_cumulative Numeric vector cumulative censored time point

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
text: function processes individual patient data create aggregate summaries mimic published Kaplan-Meier tables. Number risk represents patients yet experienced event censored time point.

title: Create Kaplan-Meier Style Summary Table from Simulated Data — summaryKM
code: # First simulate data time_points <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) hazard_rates <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  sim_data <- simPE(   n = 200,   time_points = time_points,   hazard_rates = hazard_rates,   max_time = 24 )  # Create KM table km_summary <- summaryKM(sim_data, time_points) print(km_summary$n_risk) #> [1] 200 139  93  47  20 print(km_summary$n_censored_cumulative) #> [1] 0 3 3 6 7

what: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
text: function conducts comprehensive simulation study validate performance hazard estimation methods using person-years approach implemented mimicsurv package.

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
code: validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points,   true_hazard_rates,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200, 500),   n_simulations = 100,   max_followup = NULL,   censoring_prob = 0.1,   use_pweall = FALSE )

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
text: true_time_points Time points defining intervals simulation true_hazard_rates True hazard rates interval sample_sizes Vector sample sizes test (default: c(100, 200, 500)) n_simulations Number simulation replications (default: 100) max_followup Maximum follow-time (default: max time_points) censoring_prob Probability random censoring (default: 0.1) use_pweall Logical, whether use PWEALL package available (default: FALSE)

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
text: List containing: simulation_parameters Input parameters true values detailed_results Detailed results sample size summary_statistics Summary statistics across sample sizes

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
text: function performs following steps sample size: Generate simulated data piecewise exponential distribution Create Kaplan-Meier style summary tables Apply hazard estimation method Calculate bias, MSE, coverage statistics Summarize performance across replications Performance metrics include: Bias: Mean difference estimated true values MSE: Mean squared error Coverage: Proportion estimates within acceptable range Convergence rate: Proportion successful estimations

title: Comprehensive Simulation Study for Hazard Estimation Validation — validate_mimicsurv
code: # Small simulation study true_times <- c(0, 6, 12, 18, 24) true_hazards <- c(0.05, 0.08, 0.12, 0.15)  validation_result <- validate_mimicsurv(   true_time_points = true_times,   true_hazard_rates = true_hazards,   sample_sizes = c(100, 200),   n_simulations = 50,   censoring_prob = 0.15 ) #> Running simulations for sample size 100... #> Running simulations for sample size 200...  # View summary statistics print(validation_result$summary_statistics) #>       sample_size convergence_rate median_bias median_mse #> n_100         100                1   0.1380898  1.4420564 #> n_200         200                1   0.1884929  0.5600045

title: mimicsurv 0.1.0
